title: 110_hr1679
content: The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" aims to deny financial resources to Cuba and deter foreign investments that threaten US national security, Florida's marine environment, and the Cuban people's well-being. It also seeks to prevent the development of Cuba's petroleum resources. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 is amended to exclude aliens who contribute to Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources off its coast. The Secretary of State must deny visas and exclude from the US any alien who invests $1,000,000 or more in enhancing Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources off its coast. Spouses, minor children, or agents of such individuals are also included. The Secretary may waive this if certified on a case-by-case basis to congressional committees. The Secretary of State can waive visa denial for individuals investing in Cuba's petroleum development if critical medical reasons, litigation, or specific Act requirements are met. Definitions include the Cuban Communist Party as an agent, and investment activities related to petroleum resources. Investment in Cuba's petroleum development includes activities like entering contracts for development, purchasing ownership shares, or participating in royalties, earnings, or profits. The amendment allows for participation in royalties, earnings, or profits related to petroleum development contracts. It also includes the sale or purchase of goods, services, or technology related to such development. The effective date of this amendment applies to aliens seeking admission to the United States after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. Imposition of sanctions and prohibition on facilitation of development of Cuba's petroleum resources. If the President determines that a person has made an investment of $1,000,000 or more contributing to Cuba's petroleum development, sanctions will be imposed, including prohibiting loans and guarantees and export sanctions. The text chunk discusses the prohibition of extending credit for exporting goods or services to sanctioned persons, imposing export sanctions under various acts, and prohibiting financial institutions from certain activities with sanctioned persons. The financial institution is prohibited from being designated as a primary dealer in US Government debt instruments and from serving as an agent or repository for US Government funds. Sanctions imposed will be treated as one or two sanctions under this section. Additionally, the United States Government is prohibited from procuring goods or entering contracts with the financial institution. Sanctions imposed under this section will be treated as one or two sanctions. The United States Government is prohibited from procuring goods or entering contracts with sanctioned persons. Sanctions will terminate if the President certifies that certain requirements have been met. It is unlawful for US persons to assist Cuba in developing petroleum resources. The Secretary of State must provide reports every 180 days. The Secretary of State must report every 180 days on investments exceeding $1,000,000 that enhance Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources in submerged lands off its coast. The Secretary of State must report on investments that enhance Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources, including details on the values and identities of investors, sanctions imposed, and environmental impact assessments. The Secretary of State, in consultation with other agencies, must submit an annual report assessing the environmental impact of Cuba's petroleum development on submerged lands off Cuba's coast and Florida's marine environment, using environmental impact statements as a model. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, including terms like "person", "property", "traffics", "investment", and "petroleum resources" as outlined in the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996. It also expands the definition of "person" to include foreign subsidiaries and includes the Cuban Communist Party under the terms "agent" and "instrumentality".
